Why this parameter is removed in PS3? If you set the class "_ip_version", then you don't need to check "CONF.network_feature_enabled.ipv6" again.

This breaks the test, look at the Zuul results for PS2 (https://storage.bhs.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_70a/783802/2/check/neutron-tempest-plugin-scenario-openvswitch/70a2971/testr_results.html)

CONF.network_feature_enabled.ipv6 check occurs in parent class: https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/+/refs/heads/master/neutron_tempest_plugin/api/base.py#90
so we don't need to double-check it in this method.

Sorry for the ping pong, but you need to check more config parameters. Those IPv6 tests should check
1) CONF.network_feature_enabled.ipv6 is enabled. This should be implemented here, in this method
2) CONF.network_feature_enabled.ipv6_subnet_attributes, that could be checked in the specific methods using those parameters (as in PS2).

So, IMO, you need this method checking CONF.network_feature_enabled.ipv6 in general for all tests under this class and what you have implemented in PS2 for each method checking CONF.network_feature_enabled.ipv6_subnet_attributes.

deployment/ironic/ironic-conductor-conta.message:
So ultimately, we shouldn't set this for PXE. Ironic has two interfaces, ipxe and pxe. We want people to be able to independently use them as makes sense. Overriding them is just wrong.

This entire config is ironic's classic PXE interface settings and not iPXE
It was just my mistake(or mislook) and I thought this was pointing to uefi_ipxe_bootfile_name. Maybe we can just remove these definitions and rely on defaults defined in puppet-ironic.

So what I should have done was not change the value but remove this overrides completely because this parameter is for PXE boot while ipxe.efi is for iPXE boot. Because the change in puppet-ironic has been backported, we should backport this back to train as well.

I have create a separate commit to set "iPXE" parameters to enforce usage of snponly.efi, which I initially intended... If snponly.efi is a preferred option then backporting that patch would make sense, too.

I think there is an interesting twist here.
there is an option for allowing Tier-1s to use a separate edge cluster path (edge_cluster). In this case the Tier-1 router would be already using its own edge cluster and should not be moved to a new cluster.

I think before setting the edge cluster path we can check if:
- the edge_cluster option is set, or
- verify that the tier1's current edge cluster matches the 'old' T0's edge cluster
can we make the process easier by only picking external networks?

neutron/db/quota/api.py.message: Won't it rollback more than we expect?
hmm, but if any error will happen up to this point in transaction, we will not be able to commit it without rolling back. I don't think if there is other way to do it. Any ideas?

Yeah, that's why skipping DB error in the middle of transaction is doubtful. IMO we can catch and skip error only if we're sure method owns transaction, or in other words, if it starts transaction. So we need to find where transaction is started and add both @utils.skip_exceptions(db_exc.DBError) and @transaction_guard there. WDYT? I'd also wait for Rodolfo's opinion.

That was my mistake when I changed this method.

This method "remove_reservation" is supposed to create its own DB session, using the context given. This session should be unique for the method execution (decorator in L204). Regardless of the result, any other DB transaction in this context should not be affected.

The problem I see now is where this method is called [1]: inside an upper session. "QUOTAS.commit_reservation" and "resource_registry.set_resources_dirty" should be executed in their own sessions (actually "resource_registry.set_resources_dirty" is irrelevant with the new DB "no-lock" driver)

As commented in [2], if a reservation is not removed at the end of an API call, it will be removed automatically when testing for expired reservations. In case of having several reservations, each one will be treated independently (this is not usual, most of API calls will create one single reservation).

The problem is that we use both the v2 API and the Pecan controllers. Both have different paths. The second will call the Pecan hooks, including the quota controller. There we can remove [3] to solve this problem.

In v2 API, the reservation is removed in [4]. Same as in [3], I recommend to remove this context.

We also call this method in [5]. What I recommend is to move this call out of this context.

The last recommendation is to add to this method a transaction guard decorator, to ensure "remove_reservation" is always called from outside an active session, forcing it to create its own one.

I'll push another one with the solution I propose, isolating the reservation removal transactions that is the initial goal of [2].

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/79445f12be3a9ca892672fe0e016336ef60877a2/neutron/pecan_wsgi/hooks/quota_enforcement.py#L80-L85
[2]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/805031
[3]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/79445f12be3a9ca892672fe0e016336ef60877a2/neutron/pecan_wsgi/hooks/quota_enforcement.py#L80
[4]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/79445f12be3a9ca892672fe0e016336ef60877a2/neutron/api/v2/base.py#L501-L506
[5]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/79445f12be3a9ca892672fe0e016336ef60877a2/neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py#L138-L140

What I meant on the previous comment was that you need to wait here for two things: first for the reconciliation to happen, i.e., for triggering the recovery of the loadbalancer (LB_RECONCILE_TIMEOUT), but then you also need to wait for octavia to actually create the loadbalancer (i.e., addd an extra LB_TIMEOUT). Since, there are two steps:
1) patch the status, which is when the reconciliation is triggered and the action to recreate the loadbalancer starts
2) the recreation of the loadbalancer itself on the OpenStack side of things. And this takes time on the gates where this is run, so we need LB_TIMEOUT (the timeout we wait for the loadbalancer to be created)

We probably need this here as well:

      - openstack/octavia-tempest-plugin

Actually - no. It is needed only when we pull octavia bits, which takes a place in kuryr-kubernetes-octavia-base job - which is ovn based, and add octavia load balancer support - ovn-provider by default for Neutron OVN, and amphora by default for Neutron OVS.

So the idea here was to differentiate between kuryr being based on Neutron in two variants: OVN and OVS, while two other jobs with octavia in the name are adding loadbalancer to those two variants: ovn-provider and amphora respectively.

The reason behind it was to support Neutron OVN + ovn-provider or amphora, which is pretty simple, as adding Octavia dependencies to kuryr-kubernetes-base-ovn (see the hierarchy on the commit message). 

I guess, that one of the base job can be removed (merge kuryr-kubernetes-base-ovs + kuryr-kubernetes-octavia-base-ovs), since there is no further use for kuryr-kubernetes-base-ovs. As for OVN - I guess having jobs for neutron and octavia separately makes relatively easy to define jobs which have either ovn-provider or amphora as an dependency.

Thoughts?
Alright, so it's probably needed at kuryr-kubernetes-tempest-amphora to prevent it from failing.

Perhaps I should omit "ovn" part in amphora test, to have it clear (or add "ovn" for every job name).

You're right, no need to say "ovn" on amphora job. Anyway having an amphora job on the gate pipeline is beneficial, this is where CI would protect from a combination of two independent patches breaking support for Amphora. And Amphora has totally different code paths, so it's important to exercise them as well.

tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_update.py.message: i would use utils.get_default_working_dir here instead of os.environ.get('HOME')

Why are we keeping this command? There is no plan and stack. Are we expecting host_entries to change during the update prepare/run to re-run those again?

That role is only required to run during deploy/scale-out AFAIK.

I didn't go through and check each and every part of the update_steps to compare the diffs between that and deploy_steps. I just added it back to address some of the concerns that were raised.

Maybe @Sofer Athlan-Guyot has some additional comments. I believe host entries was just an example of one of the possibly differences.

If we end up deciding that we want it to stay, then the implementation in this patchset should be sufficient since the playbooks will already be rendered by the prepare. So if we decide we DO want converge to stay, then all it would need to do is run the deploy_steps_playbook.yaml rather than doing anything with Heat.

I think even if there is no technical change required by the deploy_steps_playbook. It's probably not the worst thing to be doing a deployment at the end of a minor update using the latest set of playbooks. That way, at least if something was updated in tripleo-heat-templates, the change will be applied to the environment.

The change proposed here will at least reduce the complexity and time requirements for running a converge by no longer requiring a Stack update. From a UX perspective, it's a little less complicated since they don't need to provide all of the -e environment files. Simply running `openstack overcloud update converge` will be all that is required.

Running deploy_steps_playbook in converge step would unnecessarily increase the update time as the stack/rendered playbooks are not changing at all. If we need to run deploy_steps_playbook after minor update for some reason, we probably should add in UpdateRun like major upgrade[1].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/constants.py#L96

rally/rally-plugins/dynamic-workloads/dy.message: What will be the value of DynamicWorkload.browbeat_dir ?

The browbeat_dir variable that was being used in shift_on_stack.py earlier is not thread safe. If one iteration fails with error, it may forget to switch back to the original browbeat directory, and all iterations after that will fail because of that.
The DynamicWorkload.browbeat_dir variable will have the location of the base browbeat directory(/home/stack/browbeat most of the time). This will be set as a class variable and not a member of the object, so it will be set only for the first iteration that is run and all subsequent iterations will use the value that is set by the first iteration. This is to prevent the previous error from occuring.
